bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter Reed, November 26, 1901

div1.p: Kean offers Reed continued encouragement and strategy for the Surgeon General's post.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter Reed, November 26, 1901
div1.opener:
To Major Walter Reed, U.S.A.
Confidential-
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA.
OFFICE OF SUPERINTENDENT
DEPARTMENT OF CHARITIES.
HAVANA.
Nov. 26th
My dear Commandante
div1.p:
I have just returned
from a three weeks inspec-
tion trip to Santiago and
the east end of the island
and find yours of the 5th
awaiting me- I like the
spirit of this letter much
better than the one of which
I complained to you in mine
written while en route to
Santiago, It is more the tone
of the runner & less that of
the waiter - and sounds as
if when the Pegasus of
Opportunity comes bounding
by - (or flitting as the case may be)
that you will be ready to
seize him & mount-
Well I never heard tell of
such a crop of candidates
I think that even your modesty
should not suffer in moving
along in such a procession
Col. Havard who by the way
is going to Fort Monroe told
me that O'Reilly had written
to him to ask that he speak
to Wood in OR's behalf.
He did so yesterday just before
the General sailed for N.Y.
I asked him what the General
said- H. replied that the
General said nothing but
looked thoughtful- I did
not get a chance to speak
to him before he sailed
but asked McCoy who is in
the secret to remind him of
his promise & ask him to take you to
see the President & the Secy- McCoy is
his aide & went with him, & is a very
good friend of ours & an able young
fellow- The General will be in N.Y. by
the 28th and will probably be in Washington
next week- Be sure & have him take you
to see the Secy or at any rate speak to the
Secy in your behalf as well as to the Pres-
I will write the “proper paragraph” for the
A. & N. without delay -- but you must catch
the Pegasus in Washington next week-
If you do this you can go back to your
laboratory & to the hunt for the “small fine
bacillus” that can crawl through a Pas-
teur filter, with an easy conscience, & the
feeling that Pour. Peg. is on a lariat & tied
up at your back door- So old man
Maus is on the trail too! & La Garde & Carter
& Munson! I would like for half an hour
to hear Arthur in the subject of Maus as
a possible S.G. Think I will have to write
to him on the subject & get a rise- Say
it would be a great day for the Army
Nurse Corps wouldn't it! Well keep me
informed of all the gossip of the “willing
ones” and especially of your interview with
Gen. Wood- I find the work piled mountains
high here during my absence-
